body: I ran qtconsole on ipython (with ipython qtconsole --pylab inline and wanted to make a plot, but it did not work. Shortly, plot command does not work in qtconsole either (even if I import it from matplotlib.pyplot).
When you say 'dying,' what do you mean? What errors do you see, in either the terminal or the qtconsole?

Hi,

Let me first share what is written in the poping window  when this error arises :

The kernel appears to have died. It will restart automatically.

python quit unexpectedly.

Click Reopen to open the application again. Click Report to see more detailed information and send a report to Apple.

Additionally, in the terminal, I get : 

levent$ ipython notebook --pylab=inline --NotebookManager.notebook_dir=/Users/levent/
2014-05-28 15:09:32.092 [NotebookApp] Using existing profile dir: u'/Users/levent/.ipython/profile_default'
2014-05-28 15:09:32.095 [NotebookApp] WARNING | Starting all kernels in pylab mode is not recommended,
    and will be disabled in a future release.
    Please use the %matplotlib magic to enable matplotlib instead.
    pylab implies many imports, which can have confusing side effects
    and harm the reproducibility of your notebooks.
2014-05-28 15:09:32.150 [NotebookApp] Serving local MathJax from /Users/levent/.ipython/profile_default/static/mathjax/MathJax.js at /static/mathjax/MathJax.js
2014-05-28 15:09:32.450 [NotebookApp] The port 8888 is already in use, trying another random port.
2014-05-28 15:09:32.452 [NotebookApp] Serving notebooks from local directory: /Users/levent/
2014-05-28 15:09:32.453 [NotebookApp] 0 active kernels 
2014-05-28 15:09:32.453 [NotebookApp] The IPython Notebook is running at: http://localhost:8889/
2014-05-28 15:09:32.453 [NotebookApp] Use Control-C to stop this server and shut down all kernels (twice to skip confirmation).
2014-05-28 15:10:24.081 [NotebookApp] Kernel started: f723526a-25a7-41c4-b284-7fd515bce712
2014-05-28 15:10:59.844

Also, I noticed that if I use %pylab or %matplotlib instead of writing %pylab inline, it actually allows the graph to be plotted in a seperate window. But, the plot cannot be placed in the same ipython notebook. So, something is wrong with whatever is making the ipython notebook use the "inline" property.

What do you suggest?

Since the qtconsole itself is crashing, it's probably an issue with the Qt package in Anaconda. What is the output of `conda list`?

The `pylab/matplotlib` question is unrelated, but we are removing support for specifying `--pylab` at the notebook command-line. `--pylab` is just a shortcut for `%pylab`. So if you were doing `--pylab inline`, the recommended approach is now (in the notebook):

```
%matplotlib inline
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
```

`%matplotlib` with no `inline` argument selects the default (not inline) matplotlib backend.

Thanks for your quick reply :)

This one may be an issue: `DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH: :/usr/local/lib`

Does it help to do `unset DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH`?
Unfortunately, the problem remains the same after unsetting DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH :(

By the way, the command you see in the beginning of my terminal, i.e. 

levent$ ipython notebook --pylab=inline --NotebookManager.notebook_dir=/Users/levent/

is imposed by an AppleScript (taken from a recipe to install Python) to turn into an App to open .ipynb files from Finder by double clicking. I can still plot in a seperate graphic backend (not inline though) by writing

%matplotlib 
Output : Using matplotlib backend: MacOSX
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
x = frange(0,pi,.1)
plt.plot(x,sin(x))
Output : [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D at 0x10800f090>] and the plot in a seperate graphic backend.

Do you think that the problem could be solved by changing the code in the AppleScript?
If it's only inline that's failing, libpng seems like the culprit. Do you perhaps have libpng in /usr/local/lib?
No, I don't have libpng in /usr/local/lib.

I did 

tar xvf  libpng-1.6.10.tar.gz
cd libpng-1.6.10
./configure
make
sudo make install

to install libpng. When I wanted to open .ipynb file, the following output has been displayed in the terminal :

I fixed it by not calling pylab and using `%matplotlib` instead.

@Carreau I have this problem today too. And I found out that it only happens when I set the figure size to be large. The following code snippet works. However, if I set the `figsize` to be greater than 300, the kernel just keeps dying. @gezer2 What was your `figsize`?

```
%matplotlib inline

import matplotlib.pylot as plt

plt.figure(figsize=(200, 200))
```
If that's the cause, it may be a duplicate of #9676
